toc_entry.title: Advice From the Experts
toc_entry.description: We gave a bunch of smart Texans $50,000. (Okay, we didn’t really, we just said we did.) The money comes with these strings attached: it has to be invested in Texas now, and the investments have to pay off by 1996.

toc_entry.title: Against the Grain
toc_entry.description: One school of thought holds that when the economy is in a nosedive, that’s the time to go into business. At least that’s what a farmer, an oilman, a developer, and a banker believe.

toc_entry.title: Lessons From the Golden Apple
toc_entry.description: Empty office buildings . . . bankrupt developers . . . budget deficits. It’s Manhattan, 1975. Things sure have changed, and by learning from some Yankee real estate barons, maybe we can find a way out of our troubles.

toc_entry.title: Famous Fixers
toc_entry.description: They have done it all: saved New York City and Massachusetts, written economic classics, created new companies, and turned old ones around. Now, at our request, they’re fixing Texas.

toc_entry.title: Making It In the Bust
toc_entry.description: At a time when Texas seems to have lost its gift for creating fortunes, there has emerged a group of entrepreneurs who are making money by catering to the needs of people who are going broke.

toc_entry.title: The Last Resort
toc_entry.description: Texans are always looking for a new frontier, a place where business people can do business without worrying about a lot of bureaucrats. Want to make it in Texas today? Come to Belize.

toc_entry.title: The Wright House
toc_entry.description: For the first time since Sam Rayburn’s day, the Speaker of the House will be a Texan. And if Jim Wright of Fort Worth is to be successful, he’ll have to remember what Rayburn taught him.

toc_entry.title: And A Piñata In A Pear Tree
toc_entry.description: In eight square blocks of Nuevo Laredo you can sample a cactus taco, hone your bargaining skills, and buy the best Christmas gifts on the border.

toc_entry.title: Touch Me, Feel Me, Heal Me!
toc_entry.description: I was curious when I found that three of my friends had delved into the mysteries of psychic surgery. After three “bloody operations” of my own, I knew what it was all about. About $30 a minute.

toc_entry.title: No Dancin’ In Anson
toc_entry.subtitle: Back Roads
toc_entry.description: It doesn’t matter whether you want to two-step or tango. In this church-run town, one commandment rules supreme: Thou Shalt Not Boogie.

toc_entry.title: Short And Sweet
toc_entry.subtitle: Food
toc_entry.description: Festive Mexican pastries give a new perspective on snacking. Here’s where to find them.

toc_entry.title: Scratch Shot
toc_entry.subtitle: Movies
toc_entry.description: The Color of Money veers off into technique; Police goes flaccid; Menage succumbs to mystification; Round Midnight reduces jazz to a dirge; Something Wild has a lurid kick.

toc_entry.title: Wide-Open Blues
toc_entry.subtitle: Jazz
toc_entry.description: From James Clay to John Park, Texas tenor sax masters prove their mettle on new Lps.

toc_entry.title: Reporter
toc_entry.description: Screaming headlines and shameless photos make Laredo’s El Arma! the largest-selling Spanish weekly in the U.S.; Norbert Lyssy has miles to go before he sleeps (soundly); within our midst lies an alien and insurgent clan, the New England Society of Texas.

toc_entry.title: The Quidnunc
toc_entry.description: Keeping up with the Perots; pomp-adoring Charlie Sexton; sewing up the ses-quilt-centennial.

toc_entry.title: State Secrets
toc_entry.description: How Sheik Yamani’s departure will affect the price of oil; what the new immigration law will do to Texas; analyzing the election returns.
